channel.title: Nginx or lighttpd
channel.description:
Has anyone ever used either, or preferably both, of these? I'm considering switching from lighttpd to nginx for this website. Anyway, what do you think?
edit: Used nginx for the first time, kinda. While moparisthebest.com is still being attacked, I took this general idea and adapted it for my uses: http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/nginx-proxy-cache-integrator/installation/ Anyway, it's now sitting in front of moparisthebest.com and I don't notice any slowdown at all. It's much better than what I was using before, pound.
edit2: Running debian stable, an IRC server, and nginx proxying all traffic to moparisthebest.com, with SSL and gzip compression, I'm using 22mb of ram, and maybe 15% of the CPU. Cool stuff.

item.title: Nginx or lighttpd
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

From what I know right now, nginx can do everything lighttpd can do, and vice-versa for the most part. It’s usually apache that has more features that some people can’t part with, but when I went with lighttpd I solved everything I needed apache for.

item.title: Nginx or lighttpd
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

You could use nginx alone, sure. Some reasons for proxying script requests I can think of are vhosts, caching, resource/load distribution. From what I remember nginx does have some level of support for a lot of those and other “standard” httpd features, but depending on what you need it might be beneficial to use the proxy setup.

I guess it also depends on how much of a mess your current setup is, or how much of a mess it needs to be. Only way to really find out how effective any solution will be is by testing it, I suppose.

Read full topic

item.title: Nginx or lighttpd
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

c|p:

It’s been mentioned, but use nginx to serve static content (images, javascript, CSS) and proxy other requests to lighttpd (*.php, I guess).

I thought about it, but I don’t really see a need. Lighttpd basically ‘proxies’ php requests to fastcgi 'servers, and nginx can handle it the same way. So I don’t see why I wouldn’t just scrap lighttpd all together.

What you are talking about most people do with apache, to cleanly handle php apps that rely on mod_php and .htaccess etc.
